newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian stocks meander to weaker close.
newsitem.headline: Australian stocks meander to weaker close.

text.p: The Australian share market meandered to a weaker close on Thursday, having spent the day trapped in a 10 point range with little incentive to attempt escape.
July balance of payments figures, one possible market motivator, came in on expectations and was promptly ignored.
The All Ordinaries index lost 4.9 points to close at 2279.3 while September share index futures dipped five points to close at 2279, a 0.3 point discount to the index.
Turnover ended at impressive levels as August series options reached expiry.
While the market came off its lows in the afternoon, players said they had little to work with, resulting in the day's basically flat performance.
"It improved in the afternoon. Commonwealth Bank led the way back even though BHP went into reverse," said broker Kevin Lourey of brokerage Peake Lands Kirwan.
"There is no real reason for it to be as flat as it is. Volumes are quite good."
Others traders agreed, saying the market had been essentially rudderless with the options expiry probably as strong a force as any on the day.
"There was not much to work with and that is exactly what it did - not much," said a Sydney-based dealer.
"Options-related trade accounted for a lot of the business and the balance of payments surprised no-one."
Strongest performance of the day came from gas utility, AGL, whose shares streaked to record highs, fuelled by a record full year net profit of A$124.3 million (US$98.6 million).
Other companies to report included minerals sands and base metals miner, RGC, which posted a 46.6 percent rise in full year net profit to A$142.81 million. Its shares closed fractionally firmer.
Rises outnumbered falls by a ratio of about 11 to 10, while about 31 percent of stocks traded remained steady.
